item.title: Simulation and its discontents
item.description: An excellent short adventure through the ways computers simulate the world around us and how that changes our perception of the world and computers. Especially relevant for today's world of AI.
item.libraryRSS:author: Sherry Turkle
item.libraryRSS:title: Simulation and its discontents

item.title: The Lathe of Heaven
item.description: Excellent! Dreams as simulations. The perils of agency. A vivid description of a wonderful unique premise. This could easily have gone off the rails but Ursula is a master and this was amazing. The ending at first gave me pause but I think I've come to terms with it and embrace the taoist reading.. Beautiful writing.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ursula K. Le Guin
item.libraryRSS:title: The Lathe of Heaven

item.title: The maniac
item.description: Super engrossing. I had just watched the AlphaGo documentary and AI is of course 100% of the discourse and so this felt very timely but also timeless. I slightly preferred When We Cease to Understand the World but this was a close second. Excellent.
item.libraryRSS:author: Benjamín Labatut
item.libraryRSS:title: The maniac

item.title: How the light gets in
item.description: Wow. Thank you Brian for this amazing book. Poetry, writing, spirituality, self publishing and so much more. This was part autobiography, part writing manual and part manifesto for creativity and believing in yourself. Magical. Highly recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Pat Schneider
item.libraryRSS:title: How the light gets in

item.title: When We Cease to Understand the World
item.description: One of my all time faves. What an astonishing book. Mathematics, insanity, creativity. Highly recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Benjamín Labatut
item.libraryRSS:title: When We Cease to Understand the World

item.title: Moonbound
item.description: A fresh new approach! I admire Robin's attempt at something decidedly new and fresh and form-breaking. The writing certainly kept me reading and I overall enjoyed it but it felt a little kitchen-sink-esque with maybe too many new ideas all at once? Also I think there's some core Arthurian analogy that I didn't quite make sense of... But overall an enjoyable read.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Sloan
item.libraryRSS:title: Moonbound

item.title: Guest Lecture
item.description: A weird little novel that I mostly enjoyed. I think the core message was supposed to land more aspirationally but the anxiety of the main character felt like it got in the way a bit too much?
item.libraryRSS:author: Martin Riker
item.libraryRSS:title: Guest Lecture

item.title: Boys
item.description: Read this on Eliot Peper's recommendation and loved it! A unique kind of setup and really nicely written. Kept me reading and engrossed. Recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Katie Hafner
item.libraryRSS:title: Boys

item.title: The Space Between Worlds
item.description: Passable sci-fi with an interesting premise. The world was well crafted and the core mechanic was novel but the characters always felt a bit flat and the romance pretty far contrived!
item.libraryRSS:author: Micaiah Johnson
item.libraryRSS:title: The Space Between Worlds

item.title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
item.description: A fast read, I enjoyed it in a kind of summer-beach-read kind of way. Had some fun moments.
item.libraryRSS:author: V. E. Schwab
item.libraryRSS:title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue

item.title: The Steerswoman
item.description: I read this on recommendation from A Working Library and it didn't disappoint! Great writing and a unique world full of intrigue and more questions than answers...
item.libraryRSS:author: Rosemary Kirstein
item.libraryRSS:title: The Steerswoman

item.title: The Stone Sky
item.description: While I loved the series overall the third book really felt flat and didn't work for me. It's hard to put my finger on why but something really missed here...
item.libraryRSS:author: N. K. Jemisin
item.libraryRSS:title: The Stone Sky

item.title: The Obelisk Gate
item.description: A great continuation of the series.
item.libraryRSS:author: N. K. Jemisin
item.libraryRSS:title: The Obelisk Gate

item.title: The Fifth Season
item.description: Engaging rich descriptions - loved the underlying premise and the world that was built.
item.libraryRSS:author: N. K. Jemisin
item.libraryRSS:title: The Fifth Season

item.title: Spy Games
item.description: Such pace! Loved the descriptions and characters.
item.libraryRSS:author: Adam Brookes
item.libraryRSS:title: Spy Games

item.title: Night heron
item.description: Loved this! I don't read spy novels very often but Robin Sloan recommended it and I loved the story and the fast paced action. Fun change of pace - and there's some great writing in there. Recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Adam Brookes
item.libraryRSS:title: Night heron

item.title: Mountain in the Sea
item.description: Fun to read this against the backdrop of GPT3/GPT4! I enjoyed the book but found it kind of fizzled out at the end. I was hoping it was going to work towards some kind of crescendo but found the ending just kind of weak. But I still enjoyed the read.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ray Nayler
item.libraryRSS:title: Mountain in the Sea

item.title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
item.description: What a fun read! Poignant, fun and really engrossing. It reminded me of hints of Kavalier and Clay by Michael Chabon at times though I don't think it had quite the same depth. Recommended though!
item.libraryRSS:author: Gabrielle Zevin
item.libraryRSS:title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow

item.title: Captains of the sands
item.description: Love the style and sense of wonder that Jorge writes with. Perhaps I should read the other Bahia books in the series...
item.libraryRSS:author: Jorge Amado
item.libraryRSS:title: Captains of the sands

item.title: Suitcase Clone
item.description: A lovely novella from Robin Sloan that builds on the Robin Sloan Cinematic Universe...! Fast pasted and full of intrigue. Definitely left me wanting more!
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Sloan
item.libraryRSS:title: Suitcase Clone

item.title: Popisho
item.description: What a magical lush book. Ugly, raw, squelchy. The opposite of the Ruth Ozeki book I just read... Popisho is full of exquisite descriptions, magical realism, surreal nonsense and raw, bloody, colorful magic. Full of gods and humans at their best and worst I absolutely loved this book. If you're looking for something that is a riot of color, emotion and humanity then this is it.
item.libraryRSS:author: Leone Ross
item.libraryRSS:title: Popisho

item.title: The Book of Form and Emptiness
item.description: While at times Ruth Ozeki's writing is lyrical and magical, mostly this book felt kind of sterile. Neither of the main characters feel deeply explored and the most interesting characters (the aleph and the bottleman) are really only side events. Overall the book tasted like it had been aged in steel barrels and I was left wanting something more full bodied, more lyrical, more vivid.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ruth Ozeki
item.libraryRSS:title: The Book of Form and Emptiness

item.title: Assassin's Fate
item.description: Oof. That concludes reading all 16 of the realm of the elderlings books. I haven't kept detailed notes on them but I'm so glad that I read them all and read them in order. In many ways Nighteyes is the main character. These last three books tie together so many threads and loose ends - the storyline is dark but the ending is magical. Robin Hobb has such a powerful command of both small characters and giant worlds.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Assassin's Fate

item.title: Fool's fate
item.description: Are there stronger characters than the Fitz and the Fool? What depth of emotion. This series is a magical climax and feels like it rivals the original assassin trilogy! Loved reading this series.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Fool's fate

item.title: The Golden Fool
item.description: WHAT! So many mysteries unraveling, starting, crossing. Such emotionally charged scenes. Not giving anything away but this book is a big one.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: The Golden Fool

item.title: Fool's Errand
item.description: LOVE returning to Fitz and the Fool. I'm so deep in the Robin Hobb world now....
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Fool's Errand

item.title: Ship of Destiny
item.description: Wow! Another trilogy down. I love the callbacks and hints for the original series. Onwards!
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Ship of Destiny

item.title: The Mad Ship
item.description: Now things are getting interesting! Love the origin story for the live ships - what an incredible dark backdrop to the whole saga.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: The Mad Ship

item.title: Ship of Magic
item.description: Onwards into the Robin Hobb cinematic universe! This series starts somewhat slowly but I love the all new (or is it!) version of live ships and their unique "magic".
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Ship of Magic

item.title: Assassin's Quest
item.description: I love this trilogy so much. This is my third or fourth full re-read since I was a teenager and it remains magical each time. Such world building, characters and adventure. Onwards to the remaining.... *checks notes*.... 14 books!
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Assassin's Quest

item.title: Royal Assassin
item.description: That last line!! Such depth of characters. I really love this series. World building, unique ideas around magic, politics, love, wolves, assassins! Love it. Just as good as I remember.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Royal Assassin

item.title: Assassin's Apprentice
item.description: Diving back into an epic read of the 17 Robin Hobb books. The farseer trilogy is my all time fave and I've read these books several times before but I'm starting here to read them all in order.
item.libraryRSS:author: Robin Hobb
item.libraryRSS:title: Assassin's Apprentice

item.title: The mushroom at the end of the world
item.description: A really magical exploration of global capitalism and... mushrooms?!
item.libraryRSS:author: Anna Lowenhaupt Tsing
item.libraryRSS:title: The mushroom at the end of the world

item.title: A Memory Called Empire
item.description: What richness! The first time I've read sci-fi that felt a bit like Iain M Banks. Deep, complex, rich worlds with strong characters. An absolute treat - spanning langauge, poetry, politics, identity, memory and more. I cannot wait for the followup. After reading so much poorly written sci fi recently (Dune, The Ministry of the Future, Exhalation..) this was a refreshing breath of fresh air.
item.libraryRSS:author: Arkady Martine
item.libraryRSS:title: A Memory Called Empire

item.title: Laughter in the Dark
item.description: An airbnb read. Just lovely poetic writing - a breath of fresh air after a bunch of badly-written scifi.
item.libraryRSS:author: Vladamir Nabakov
item.libraryRSS:title: Laughter in the Dark

item.title: The Ministry for the Future
item.description: Abandoned during the free preview. Everyone is raving about this book but honestly the writing felt incredibly flat. I'm tired of sci-fi stories having bad writing :(
item.libraryRSS:author: Kim Stanley Robinson
item.libraryRSS:title: The Ministry for the Future

item.title: Exhalation
item.description: Abandoned 2/3 of the way through :( - while I quite enjoyed some of the provocations in the stories ultimately the writing didn't captivate me. Left me feeling bored so I gave it up.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ted Chiang
item.libraryRSS:title: Exhalation

item.title: Multidimensional Executive Coaching
item.description: Some great thought provoking ideas about coaching, consulting and being embedded inside organizations as an outsider. I especially love the concept in the book of overbounded or underbounded organizations.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ruth L. Orenstein
item.libraryRSS:title: Multidimensional Executive Coaching

item.title: The Player of Games
item.description: I have fond memories of the first time reading this and felt like it left a big impression on me. Re-reading this book I still loved it but the shine has come off a little - I think other culture books are perhaps better. Still, the world building (universe building!) that Iain M Banks does is like no other.
item.libraryRSS:author: Iain M. Banks
item.libraryRSS:title: The Player of Games

item.title: Dune
item.description: Started reading this while traveling through Utah and Arizona to get a feel for desert living. I enjoyed the book but definitely didn't feel like it lived up to the hype. Inventive but the characters felt a little stale.
item.libraryRSS:author: Frank Herbert
item.libraryRSS:title: Dune

item.title: Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software
item.description: A great read about internet creators, economics of production, communities, influencers, open source and more. Nadia provides a ton of real data and examples but pairs them with big ideas and concepts. Essential read.
item.libraryRSS:author: Nadia Eghbal
item.libraryRSS:title: Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software

item.title: The Uncertainty Mindset
item.description: A wonderful rich book exploring the world of high end culinary R&D to find lessons applicable for other types of organizations. A really fun read - great stories about high end cooking as well as sharp insights about food.
item.libraryRSS:author: Vaughn Tan
item.libraryRSS:title: The Uncertainty Mindset

item.title: Tomorrow Lies in Ambush
item.description: Classic sci-fi short stories recommended by Matt Webb. Some really lovely ideas and great writing! All the stories are very character-driven and often reflect more strongly on the individual characters motives and identities over the larger sci-fi conceits! Lovely. Thanks Matt!
item.libraryRSS:author: Bob Shaw
item.libraryRSS:title: Tomorrow Lies in Ambush

item.title: East of Eden
item.description: What a magnificent - truly epic work. I'm a big Steinbeck fan already and I think I even read this one previously but loved immersing myself in this wonderful story. The biblical theme is almost too strong at times but is richly counterbalanced by Steinbeck's incredibly loving character portraits. Amazing.
item.libraryRSS:author: John Steinbeck
item.libraryRSS:title: East of Eden

item.title: Veil
item.description: A really great fast-paced read. Eliot has a great knack for constructing plausible near-futures and then situating fully realized human stories within those futures. Thought provoking and enjoyable.
item.libraryRSS:author: Eliot Peper
item.libraryRSS:title: Veil

item.title: The Memory Police
item.description: While the writing style at times is captivating - like a penny falling into a deep well - often the writing was unremarkable and the plot unfolded fairly slowly. All in the book was, ironically, forgettable. That said - the ending, where bodies start to fade away really resonated during this period of lockdown and isolation - it captures the essence of my embodied self fading away into an infinite series of zoom screens.
item.libraryRSS:author: Yoko Ogawa
item.libraryRSS:title: The Memory Police

item.title: Working Identity- Unconventional Strategies for Reinventing Your Career
item.description: A wonderful meditation on career change (and life change generally) as being a process of iterating and trying on new identities. Has deep implications for independents also. Going to blog this book up. Originally found via Vaughn Tan's newsletter.
item.libraryRSS:author: Herminia Ibarra
item.libraryRSS:title: Working Identity- Unconventional Strategies for Reinventing Your Career

item.title: An Introduction to Haiku
item.description: Brian suggested I get into Haiku and pick up this book and I'm glad I did! Beautiful, easy to read intro to Haiku. The author gives great context for what Haiku is, the main poets and how to read Haiku poetry. Recommended!
item.libraryRSS:author: Harold Gould Henderson
item.libraryRSS:title: An Introduction to Haiku

item.title: Tears of the Trufflepig
item.description: A wonderful book. Like an absurdist Cormac McCarthy x Kurt Vonnegut mashup. Lyrical descriptions, wonderful characters and a wild imagination. Highly recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Fernando A. Flores
item.libraryRSS:title: Tears of the Trufflepig

item.title: A Winter’s Promise
item.description: There are moments when the lavish fantasy world and the magic contained in it sucked me in - but ultimately the character development and plot just didn't hang together to keep me reading. Good escapist reading but there are better fantasy worlds to lose yourself in than this one.
item.libraryRSS:author: Christelle Dabos
item.libraryRSS:title: A Winter’s Promise

item.title: Less
item.description: A truly delightful novel - with hints of PG Wodehouse. This book really sucked me in with magical lush writing and a great wry tone. Definitely recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Andrew Sean Greer
item.libraryRSS:title: Less

item.title: Infinite Detail
item.description: A fun quick read. There's some good language and some nice world-setting but I wish some of the characters had been more fully developed and I wish the central idea had been stronger. The ending kind of fizzles out and there could have been room for so much more here.. Good for a little lightweight-dytopia though.
item.libraryRSS:author: Tim Maughan
item.libraryRSS:title: Infinite Detail

item.title: Dead Astronauts
item.description: I think perhaps I made a mistake. I didn't realize until after I'd read it that it was part of the Borne series. Maybe that would have been useful because this book made zero sense. Like a William Burroughs book it was somehow interesting and riveting at times despite literally making no sense. Did I mention it makes no sense? The first section with the three astronauts was the most compelling..... Maybe I should read the other Borne books and it'll make more sense? But I doubt it.
item.libraryRSS:author: Jeff VanderMeer
item.libraryRSS:title: Dead Astronauts

item.title: The Nix
item.description: Abandoned 500 pages in. I tried to keep going but just couldn't. A Very Bad Book. Highly un-recommended. This is a good takedown. So many characters are badly written sexually frustrated males and it's just all round a bad book. Couple sentences worth savoring but.. ugh.
item.libraryRSS:author: Nathan Hill
item.libraryRSS:title: The Nix

item.title: A Gentleman in Moscow
item.description: Amor is a wonderful writer with so many lyrical touches, flourishes and turns of phrase. The feel of the book of politics, culture and acting in the proper way is great. Without posting spoilers there's a few themes in the book that make me feel like the book was written by a man - that some of the more emotionally rich moments are skipped over... But overall highly recommended as a fun, engaging and lyrical book.
item.libraryRSS:author: Amor Towles
item.libraryRSS:title: A Gentleman in Moscow

item.title: Tempo - timing, tactics and strategy in narrative-driven decision-making
item.description: I really should have read this years ago but I really enjoyed this piece. The core ideas around tempo of interactions, narrative time and that the kitchen is the best way to think about time will all stick with me for a while. Recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Venkatesh Rao
item.libraryRSS:title: Tempo - timing, tactics and strategy in narrative-driven decision-making

item.title: Conversation - How Talk Can Change Our Lives
item.description: A delightful little book that was a gift from my friend Brian. A little meditation on conversations, how important they are and some of the explicit and implicit ways they can go wrong. At first I thought this was going to offer solutions and ideas but mostly it just offers poetry and provocations. I think it'll stick with me for a long time though - and the art from the author scattered through the book makes a lovely little object. Thanks Brian!
item.libraryRSS:author: Theodore Zeldin
item.libraryRSS:title: Conversation - How Talk Can Change Our Lives

item.title: Recursion
item.description: A fast-paced, high-action read. A fun time-travel romp with some great characters. Ultimately I thought the premise was smart and the writing handled it well but the whole novel felt a little shallow. There were some really meaty ideas about identity and family wrapped up here that kind of got sidelined for the sake of the technology-driven plot and I thought that was a shame. Fun read though.
item.libraryRSS:author: Blake Crouch
item.libraryRSS:title: Recursion

item.title: Way Station
item.description: Lovely vintage sci-fi recommended by Chris Butler. There's aliens, teleporting and... magic? But nothing flashy happens - it's an incredibly human story. This is a really thoughtful and fresh story. Highly recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Clifford D. Simak
item.libraryRSS:title: Way Station

item.title: Idiots First
item.description: The opening line of Idiot's First is a masterpiece. 'The thin ticking of the tin clock stopped'. Loved a few of the other stories but some were definitely forgettable. I'd recommend dipping your toe in and at the very least reading the title story Idiots First.
item.libraryRSS:author: Bernard Malamud
item.libraryRSS:title: Idiots First

item.title: The Scar
item.description: Ah what delicious sludgy, dark, human texture. China Miéville's descriptive language and world building is unparalleled. This is book two (after reading Perdido Street Station last year). These books are long and luxurious so perhaps not the best entry point if you're new to his writing but if you like this kind of thing there's nothing better. My only quarrel with this book was the ending... It felt somewhat unsatisfying, or rather unfinished - where a typical book resolves this felt like the open sea was still in front of you? But it's a very minor comment as mostly the strength of this book was that every page told a lifetime of texture. Definitely going to read book three of this trilogy after a break.
item.libraryRSS:author: China Miéville
item.libraryRSS:title: The Scar

item.title: Last Night
item.description: After reading All That Is I had to wash my palette and get back to some of his delicious writing. This was much more in line with Light Years and contained some lovely moments. None of the short stories will linger with me too long but it's a short read and I'd recommend it.
item.libraryRSS:author: James Salter
item.libraryRSS:title: Last Night

item.title: Emissaries Guide to Worlding
item.description: The core idea of the masks - the cartoonist, the director, the hacker and the emissary - is wonderful and a new lens to look at the world through, so overall I'd recommend the book. But there was also an incredible over-indulgence from the author to live inside his own worlds (which feels very finite game like, not infinite game like). And the lack of people anywhere in his worlds is also problematic. That said - the book as an object is beautiful and wonderfully designed.
item.libraryRSS:author: Ian Cheng
item.libraryRSS:title: Emissaries Guide to Worlding

item.title: The Prisoner
item.description: I really enjoyed this - a delightfully British story of being trapped, like a combination of Kafka and PG Wodehouse. The plot derailed itself in a few places and there was a whole Shakespere reference that kind of went over my head but the writing was wonderful. Recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Thomas M. Disch
item.libraryRSS:title: The Prisoner

item.title: Oval
item.description: I really loved this. Distinctive, fresh writing that captures so much of the present weirdness in society while also somehow feeling timeless. The middle third dragged slightly for me but the descent into ecological weird towards the end is just wonderful and reminds me of the Annihiliation series by Jeff Vandermeer. Oh and the whole book centers on this premise of artists becoming 'consultants' which is magnificent. Recommended. Verdict- 👍🌲
item.libraryRSS:author: Elvia Wilk
item.libraryRSS:title: Oval

item.title: All That Is
item.description: A wildly disappointing read. Not that it was so bad but that having recently read Light Years I was expecting so much more. There were moments of brilliance in the writing and some of the scenes will linger with me overall the book didn't really make me feel anything. Definitely read Light Years instead.
item.libraryRSS:author: James Salter
item.libraryRSS:title: All That Is

item.title: Borderless
item.description: Book two of the Analog series. Overall I connected less with the main character in this one but connected more with the overall premise which is very thought provoking. It feels today that we are actively living through the end (or at least a phase transition) of sovereignty. Compelling and a quick read.
item.libraryRSS:author: Eliot Peper
item.libraryRSS:title: Borderless

item.title: Bandwidth
item.description: I completely devoured this book. The characters and pace keeps it flowing but the ideas will stick with me - it's grounded in a very near future and the concepts are well thought through. Excited to keep diving into Borderless next.
item.libraryRSS:author: Eliot Peper
item.libraryRSS:title: Bandwidth

item.title: The Gone Away World
item.description: A majestic feat of imagination - whirlwind story of a gong-fu epic in a world gone mad. Definitely feels like it needed better editing or structuring and was about 100 pages too long but the strength of imagination and grasp of poetry really captivated me. Picked this up off the street on the way home from kung-fu training (approriate!). I'll be reading more of his work.
item.libraryRSS:author: Nick Harkaway
item.libraryRSS:title: The Gone Away World

item.title: Light Years
item.description: This book completely destroyed me. The writing is dense and poetic like almost no one I've ever read. Did you know glass is a liquid and slowly 'flows'? This book operates on a time horizon and 'flows' through lives in a deeply transformative way. Found via Phil Gyford
item.libraryRSS:author: James Salter
item.libraryRSS:title: Light Years

item.title: Delirious New York
item.description: It's architecture writing but lyrical, magical and opinionated. A tour de force through New York's history with tons of interesting characters, ideas, explorations and more. Ideas include congestion as an organizing principle of the city, and every block being an archipelago. Wonderful and highly recommended.
item.libraryRSS:author: Rem Koolaas
item.libraryRSS:title: Delirious New York

item.title: Tomorrow In The Battle Think On Me
item.description: Abandoned. I think somewhere in this book is buried a wonderful treasure. The looping self-aware story is fundamentally interesting and new but the language that wraps around it chokes it to death. Abandoned about half way through.
item.libraryRSS:author: Javier Marias
item.libraryRSS:title: Tomorrow In The Battle Think On Me

item.title: Summerland
item.description: A wonderful original work - full of interesting characters. Ghosts! Spys! Old London! Really enjoyed this and tore through it super fast.
item.libraryRSS:author: Hannu Rajaniemi
item.libraryRSS:title: Summerland

item.title: Finite & Infinite Games
item.description: Great unique book, wonderful analogy to finite and infinite writing....
item.libraryRSS:author: James Carse
item.libraryRSS:title: Finite & Infinite Games

item.title: The Power
item.description: Provocative premise but I felt it squandered an opportunity at a deeper political and/or emotional exploration of what would happen if teenage girls gained a new incredible power. Somehow it resorted to.... fucking and fighting?
item.libraryRSS:author: Naomi Alderman
item.libraryRSS:title: The Power

item.title: Perdido Street Station
item.description: A staggering, creative, filthy, engrossing tour through a world with such magical and rich depths. No one can build worlds like China.
item.libraryRSS:author: China Mieville
item.libraryRSS:title: Perdido Street Station

item.title: Satin Island
item.description: William Gibson meets Kafka. A corporate strategy consultant / ethnographer ponders the meaning of life and searches for the Great Report.
item.libraryRSS:author: Tom McCarthy
item.libraryRSS:title: Satin Island

item.title: The Dark Dark
item.description: Tender, oozing, lyrical, dark, DARK stories of being human. Did I mention they are dark? What writing though! What imagination!
item.libraryRSS:author: Samantha Hunt
item.libraryRSS:title: The Dark Dark
